SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life's because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Western Canadian Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below, please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing and churchwork
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

JUN 17 1952
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: R.E. Ludlow, R.R. #4, M.W.
2. Your address: Box 115, Assiniboia, Sask.
3. Date: May 23, 1952
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Ontario, Canada
5. What was your father's name and occupation?: Richard Ludlow - Farmer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): August, 1905
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: Ontario, Canada

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was in my teens", etc.): 17 Years
9. What were your reasons for coming West? (Born & raised on a rented farm, owner of a home - my brother - 8 yrs., my senior & I planned on going West - where we were promised 160 acres for 100$. As soon as I was old enough - Saw + results have been good)

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?): Mostly thru R.R. excursions from Ontario to Western harvest fields. We came in 1905 & 1906 - Fare $200 to Sask. $80 back to Ontario.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have written it, please say so. If you rather have someone else do the writing at your direction, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: R. Ernest Ludlow

2. Your address: Box 115, Assiniboia

3. Date: May 23, 1954

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Caledonia, Ontario, Canada

5. What was your father's name and occupation?: Richard Ludlow - Farmer

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): August, 1905

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: Caledonia, Ontario

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.): 17 years

9. What were your reasons for coming West? Born & raised on a rented farm with no hope of becoming owner of a home - my brother - 9 yrs. old & I came on going West - where we were promised my share of the land. As soon as I was old enough - we came. Saw - results have been good.

10. How did you learn about the West? (If you have had any experience in getting information):

Mostly through R.R. excursions from Ontario to Western harvest fields. We came in 1905 - 1906 - fare paid to Sask., $5.00 back to Ontario.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? Better not disclosed—Few of them followed.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? C.P.R. To Sask.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

One fellow traveller whom we nicknamed Joe Bagram as he claimed freely of his produce—insisted on forwarding at most stops—his favorite song: "What's the roll installed up yonder Bible there?"

Another—a smoker—would approach a stranger with small pipe in mouth—ask for a pipe full of tobacco—and on receiving the strangers pouch of tobacco, would take a cup sized pipe from his pocket & proceed to fill it.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? Acetland Hotel—Walsall Sask—over night—next day my brother—two friends of his—started walking out—Sask 15 miles North of Walsall—shipped road harvests to harbor—then homesteaded—75 acres along river on a big stream—three kids—father—wife—followed—80 miles—S.W. of Moose Jaw—25 miles N.W. of Willow Beach—Sask—May—1907.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? Saskatoon—Sask—May—1907.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. Taupar School—Elmira—Sask—May—1907—after normalizing at Regina in 1906.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

A farmers son in Ontario—really harmed if—

In Sask—Brother John T. did a little carpentry—Went out with team & rack on threshing.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? Better not disclosed - Few of them followed.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? Myself & Other + Mrs. L.

13. What means of transportation did you use? C.P.R. To Sask.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way; meetings with Indians; adventures on the journey; accidents or other excitement; etc.)

One fellow brought his family of his produce - consisted of - Pending up most steps - His favorite song "What's the roll called up yonder little there."

Another - a smoker - would approach a stranger with small pipe in mouth - ask for a pipe full of tobacco - and on receiving the strangers' pouch of tobacco, would take a cup sized pipe from his pocket & proceed to fill it.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Keetana Hotel - Weldon - Sack - Everitt - Walking out of brother - two feet - Weldon - Sack - Everitt - Refund have of labor.

Some 15 miles North of Weldon - Left - Threshed - on a big stream - Threshed until - we found 25 - 75 pounds per day - 80 miles - S.W. of Moose Jaw - May 1907.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? Willow Bunch - Sack - May 1907.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Taupar School - Clinton - Near 3 - field Lake.

After moving to Regina in 1906.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Farmers Son in O.F.A. via - really learned IP.

In Sask. - Brother John Y. T. did a little carpentry.

Went out with team + rack on threshing Barns - etc.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled:

Father came 1904 - Mother followed some two yrs. (after)

Both were good pioneers - Both deceased

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

All were on a pay - Nobody had nothing and we all used it - People were sociable + had time to live - Later as civilization crept in - sociability faded - Birds + wild life scarce had known the fear of man - Shacks were small but homely - I recall six + eight people + lived on the floor of our 10x12 shack - Our shack roof leaked - I recall Brother John making bread - to escape the drip he had sought the shelter of the kitchen table covered with oil cloth.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Travel restricted to four + oxen every twenty miles

First trip M. J. saw the homestead - Crescents covered 100 miles

Took us 8 days with oxen - Parked wagons in a v. against the wind sight - The last - the snow - the snow - the snow - Several years we trailed to M. J. - with horses - Two days - arrived in one day - Youngest up returned load - and Tuesday's return completed the trip.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)

Track & M. J. Sawmills, CPR, invested the capital. The company operated some type with grain elevator. Some type until 1912.

29. How often did you shop in the early days? First Year - Planned on

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

Mail Order Waggon House closed 5-19 days - 5/11's

By mail order - Considered very valuable & Board Watch dog.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

Local company formed - Poveshell 1914

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

Came to make a home - always liked it.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1911? What reasons did they have for moving?

Some flew came to make some money—prematurely sold.

35. Did many people move away during the 1920s? Did many return?

Not many (locally)

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

Not greatly on boards of local organizations—gained position.

Local Empire Builders—branch of Grain Growers’ Association.

(People’s 1911—1912—General Secretary—Board of Directors)

H. R. (1910—President of Co-op. Assn.)

37. If you or any of your family or friends were “first” to have or do something in the district mention it here, giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combining, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post offices, villages, railway stations, farms, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place name; (2) origin and meaning of the name; (3) date of its adoption (if any) and reason for change. Give latest of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

Ruperts S.P.—Name suggested by Mrs. Jas. E. E. E. A. Australian name meaning—Prairie—Name suggested by Mrs. Jas. E. E. A. Australian name a pioneer—now deceased—Since the coming of the town name has been changed to Assiniboia S.P. in keeping with the town.

Not guilty - On Board of Local Empire Builders, Board of Directors (1911-1912) - Secretary (1910) - President of Local Empire Builders Club (4 years)

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "pioneers" to have or do something in the district mention it here, giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

Rupertsburg - Name suggested by Mrs. S. E. Ruppert

Pioneer - Now deceased. Since the coming of the town a pioneer name has been changed to Assiniboia S.D. in keeping with the Town.
